items.label: rem-note-hypocoercivity-analogy
items.title: Analogy to Classical Hypocoercivity Theory
items.content:
978: :class: tip
979: 
980: This structure is the **discrete stochastic analogue** of the classical hypocoercivity framework for kinetic PDEs (Villani, 2009; Dolbeault-Mouhot-Schmeiser, 2015):
981: 
982: **Classical Hypocoercivity (Kinetic Fokker-Planck)**:
983: - The transport operator $v \cdot \nabla_x$ generates dynamics in $x$ but is neutral on the velocity distribution.
984: - The collision operator $\mathcal{L}_v$ generates dissipation in $v$ but does not directly affect $x$.
985: - Neither operator alone contracts the full kinetic norm $\|f\|^2_{L^2} + \|\nabla_x f\|^2_{L^2}$.
986: - The augmented norm $\|f\|^2_{L^2} + \varepsilon \|\nabla_x f\|^2_{L^2}$ allows proving exponential decay by balancing the operators' effects.
987: 
988: **Our Discrete Stochastic Framework (Fragile Gas)**:
989: - The cloning operator $\Psi_{\text{clone}}$ contracts $V_{\text{Var}}$ (internal swarm structure) but may expand $W_h^2$ (inter-swarm distance via velocity resets).
990: - The kinetic operator $\Psi_{\text{kin}}$ contracts $W_h^2$ (via confining potential) but may expand $V_{\text{Var}}$ (via diffusion noise).
991: - Neither operator alone contracts the full phase-space error.
992: - The augmented Lyapunov $V_{\text{total}} = W_h^2 + c_V V_{\text{Var}} + c_B W_b$ allows proving exponential convergence by balancing the operators' synergistic dissipation.

items.label: rem-log-gap-bound-tightness
items.title: On the Tightness of the Bound
items.content:
4160: :class: note
4161: 
4162: The stated bound $\ln(1 + \kappa/V_{\max})$ is slightly conservative compared to the tight bound $\ln(1 + \kappa/(V_{\max} - \kappa))$ derived in Step 4. For most practical applications where $\kappa \ll V_{\max}$, the difference is negligible:
4163: 
4164: $$
4165: \frac{\kappa}{V_{\max} - \kappa} \approx \frac{\kappa}{V_{\max}}\left(1 + \frac{\kappa}{V_{\max}}\right)
4166: $$

items.label: rem-log-gap-bound-tight-at-vmin
items.title: Why the Bound is Tight at $V_{\min}$
items.content:
4280: :class: note
4281: 
4282: The upper bound $\ln(1 + \kappa/V_{\min})$ is achieved in the worst-case scenario where:
4283: 1. The means are separated by the maximum allowed gap $\kappa$
4284: 2. Both distributions are positioned at the bottom of the range near $V_{\min}$, where the logarithm has the steepest slope
4285: 3. One distribution is deterministic (maximizing its expected log) while the other is maximally dispersed (minimizing its expected log)

items.content:
5890: :label: rem-measurement-coupling
5891: 
5892: When analyzing two swarms $(S_1, S_2)$ in the drift analysis (Chapters 10-11), we use **synchronous coupling** of the randomness:
5893: - The same random pairing algorithm is applied to both swarms

5892: When analyzing two swarms $(S_1, S_2)$ in the drift analysis (Chapters 10-11), we use **synchronous coupling** of the randomness:

items.label: rem-position-velocity-update-difference
items.title: Position Jitter vs. Velocity Collision Model
items.content:
6161: :label: rem-position-velocity-update-difference
6162: 
6163: The cloning operator treats positions and velocities asymmetrically:
6164: 
6165: 1. **Position:** Stochastic Gaussian jitter with variance $\sigma_x^2$ breaks spatial correlations between swarms in the drift analysis.
6166: 
6167: 2. **Velocity:** Deterministic inelastic collision model (with random rotation) conserves momentum and provides controlled energy dissipation via $\alpha_{\text{restitution}}$.
6168: 
6169: This design choice has important implications:
6170: 
6171: - **Positional desynchronization** comes from explicit Gaussian noise $\mathcal{N}(0, \sigma_x^2 I_d)$

items.label: rem-coupling-benefits
items.title: Synchronous Coupling Benefits
items.content:
6348: :label: rem-coupling-benefits
6349: 
6350: The synchronous coupling ensures that:
6351: 
6352: 1. **Common randomness cancels:** When both swarms have walker $i$ in similar states and both make the same cloning decision, much of the random perturbation is shared, reducing divergence.
6353: 
6354: 2. **Worst-case expansion is bounded:** Even when the swarms make different decisions (e.g., walker $i$ clones in swarm 1 but persists in swarm 2), the expansion is controlled by the maximum displacement $D_{\text{valid}}$.

items.label: rem-synergistic-velocity-dissipation
items.title: Synergistic Dissipation Enables Net Contraction
items.content:
6838: :label: rem-synergistic-velocity-dissipation
6839: 
6840: This bounded expansion is the prerequisite for the synergistic dissipation framework. The companion document will prove that the kinetic operator provides velocity contraction:
6841: 
6842: $$
6843: \mathbb{E}_{\text{kin}}[\Delta V_{\text{Var},v}] \leq -\kappa_v V_{\text{Var},v} + C'_v
6844: $$
6845: 
6846: for some $\kappa_v > 0$ proportional to the Langevin friction $\gamma$.
6847: 
6848: When properly balanced:
6849: 
6850: $$
6851: \mathbb{E}_{\text{clone} \circ \text{kin}}[\Delta V_{\text{Var},v}] \leq -\kappa_v V_{\text{Var},v} + (C_v + C'_v)
6852: $$

items.label: rem-drift-constants-dependencies
items.title: Constants and Parameter Dependencies
items.content:
6983: :label: rem-drift-constants-dependencies
6984: 
6985: The drift constants have the following dependencies:
6986: 
6987: **Contraction rate $\kappa_x$:**
6988: - Increases with measurement quality (larger $\epsilon$ → better diversity detection)
6989: - Increases with cloning responsiveness (larger $p_{\max}$ and smaller $\varepsilon_{\text{clone}}$)
6990: - Independent of $N$ (N-uniformity from Keystone)
6991: 
6992: **Expansion bound $C_v$:**
6993: - Increases with $V_{\max}^2$ (larger velocity domain)
6994: - Increases with $\alpha_{\text{restitution}}$ (more elastic collisions)
6995: - Decreases toward zero as $\alpha_{\text{restitution}} \to 0$ (perfectly inelastic)
6996: - Independent of $N$

items.label: rem-barrier-geometric-penalty
items.title: Barrier Function as Geometric Penalty
items.content:
7074: :label: rem-barrier-geometric-penalty
7075: 
7076: The barrier function creates a "soft wall" around the boundary:
7077: 
7078: - **Far from boundary** ($d(x, \partial \mathcal{X}_{\text{valid}}) > \delta_{\text{safe}}$): No penalty, $\varphi_{\text{barrier}}(x) = 0$
7079: 
7080: - **Near boundary** ($d(x, \partial \mathcal{X}_{\text{valid}}) \leq \delta_{\text{safe}}$): Penalty increases, reducing fitness
7081: 
7082: - **At boundary:** Infinite penalty (though walkers at the boundary are dead, so this limit is never realized for alive walkers)

items.label: rem-boundary-mass-relationship
items.title: Relationship to Total Boundary Potential
items.content:
7281: :label: rem-boundary-mass-relationship
7282: 
7283: If all walkers outside the exposed set have $\varphi_{\text{barrier}}(x_i) \leq \phi_{\text{thresh}}$, then:
7284: 
7285: $$
7286: W_b(S_k) = \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i \in \mathcal{A}(S_k)} \varphi_{\text{barrier}}(x_i) \leq M_{\text{boundary}}(S_k) + \frac{k_{\text{alive}}}{N} \phi_{\text{thresh}}
7287: $$

items.label: rem-progressive-safety
items.title: Interpretation: Progressive Safety Enhancement
items.content:
7312: :label: rem-progressive-safety
7313: 
7314: This theorem formalizes the Safe Harbor mechanism:
7315: 
7316: - **When many walkers are near the boundary** ($W_b$ large), these walkers have low fitness and high cloning probability
7317: - **They are replaced by clones of interior walkers**, pulling the boundary potential down
7318: - **The contraction rate $\kappa_b$ is state-independent**, ensuring consistent safety correction regardless of swarm configuration
7319: - **The bounded offset $C_b$** accounts for walkers entering the boundary region through position jitter, but this is dominated by contraction when $W_b$ is large
7320: 
7321: **Important Consequences:**

items.label: rem-safety-margin-tuning
items.title: Safety Margin and Parameter Tuning
items.content:
7717: :label: rem-safety-margin-tuning
7718: 
7719: The equilibrium bound $C_b/\kappa_b$ can be made arbitrarily small by:
7720: 
7721: 1. **Increasing $\kappa_b$:** Use larger weight $\beta$ on the reward component in fitness, making boundary penalties more salient
7722: 
7723: 2. **Decreasing $C_b$:** Use smaller position jitter variance $\sigma_x^2$ to reduce re-entry into boundary regions after cloning
7724: 
7725: 3. **Widening safe interior:** Choose barrier function parameters to increase $\delta_{\text{safe}}$, providing more buffer before penalties activate

items.label: rem-why-vw-expands
items.title: Why Inter-Swarm Error Doesn't Contract Under Cloning
items.content:
7969: :label: rem-why-vw-expands
7970: 
7971: The cloning operator **cannot contract** $V_W$ because:
7972: 
7973: 1. **Intra-swarm mechanism:** Cloning acts **within** each swarm independently. It compares walker $i$ to its companion in the **same swarm**, not to the corresponding walker in the other swarm.
7974: 
7975: 2. **No inter-swarm communication:** The fitness evaluation and companion selection have no information about the other swarm in the coupled analysis. They cannot "know" which direction reduces $V_W$.
7976: 
7977: 3. **Stochastic desynchronization:** Even with synchronous coupling, different swarm configurations lead to different fitness landscapes, causing different cloning decisions that increase divergence.

items.label: rem-perfect-complementarity
items.title: Perfect Complementarity
items.content:
8230: :label: rem-perfect-complementarity
8231: 
8232: Notice the **exact complementarity**:
8233: - What cloning **contracts** (position, boundary), kinetic **expands** (diffusion, potential climb)
8234: - What cloning **expands** (velocity, inter-swarm), kinetic **contracts** (friction, hypocoercivity)
8235: - Both **contract** the boundary potential (layered safety)

items.label: rem-tuning-guidance
items.title: Tuning Guidance
items.content:
8386: :label: rem-tuning-guidance
8387: 
8388: In practice, the coupling constants are chosen as:
8389: 
8390: $$
8391: c_V \approx \frac{\kappa_W}{2\kappa_x}, \quad c_B \approx \frac{\kappa_W}{2\kappa_b}
8392: $$
8393: 
8394: This balances the contraction rates across components, ensuring no single component dominates the drift inequality. The factor of 2 provides safety margin.
8395: 
8396: If the system is experiencing:
8397: - **High boundary exposure:** Increase $c_B$ to weight safety more heavily
